snippet.textDisplay: This really helped me. My grandfather passed on June 2,2018 due to a heart attack. I couldn’t stop crying. I was so depressed. He always told me not to cry when he passed away. But the only thing that helped me was his dog. She laid down where he passed every night. She barked for an straight hour a neighbor said and the cops showed up and saw him dark blue on the floor. But then we couldn’t keep his dog because we weren’t allowed dogs in our house. So we have her away to my cousin. She didn’t take good care of her so she gave her back to us. 6 months later. We kept her and she helped and I helped her with my grandfather past. His dog was his best friend. But now we kept her. I hope you guys read. 😊 Thank you 😢

snippet.textDisplay:
I went thru this kind of lost. Last year, my uncle died from câncer too. I'm the youngest in my family and my is a single mother, so everybory kinda took care of us when we needed and my uncles and aunts are like moms and dads to me. My uncle was such a good person, like, he did everything for his daughters and family. He loved cooking and loved when everybory went to his house to eat and spend time together. He didn't like to drink alcohol and hated cigarets. He was a health person, His thing was food.
Then, cancer came and it was bad. He had only couple of months because it was already bad and the doctors couldn't do anything but take his pain with meds.
I couldn't understand why him, of all the bad people in this world.
when he passed I couldn't se his body, me and my mom went to the funeral only to confort my cousins and my uncles family (he was my mom's brother in law).
We didn't stay longer there, I couldn't.
After that, I couldn't stay at my aunts house, I felt like he was going to come home and cook for us, and when I remembered I felt like trash.
It took a year for me to be able to stay at the house.
He was like a father to me.
It has been a year too.
thank u for this and we are in this together.
I am really proud of you two.

Although very sick , we have little triumphs lumped in with set backs... This documentary really spoke to me.. (so far) ; what a beautiful way to honor your dad. ❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🖤♥️ Sending all the love to you.

snippet.textDisplay: i still admire the people who get to spend time with their loved ones until their last moments... i couldn't with my dad. he passed away back in 2016 very suddenly, and he showed no signs of being sick. he was just... normal. when we learned that he was in the hospital after he fainted at his work, i remember being so frantic and scared of what could happen. i couldn't stop crying cause something like this never happened to him. i was scared of the worst, so i tried to create all these scenarios in my head along the way to the hospital that i would take care of him while he was hospitalized. by the time i arrived, he was gone. it was too late. i couldn't even properly say goodbye to him. 💔

snippet.textDisplay: I can tell you from the standpoint of a person that lost my dad at 9 years old, and now 18 years old, it never gets fucking easier. It’s been almost 8 years now, and it still sometimes doesn’t feel real. I have now almost spend more of my life without my dad than with him. But I just want to say that this documentary has been so touching. You guys have been there throughout my hard days, not that you would know me or this, but I have been watching you guys thought out the years and you have always been a big source of my happiness and escape from my depression and this has just made your impact on my life even greater. Thank you, just thank you for being not only a source of happiness for me, but also a source of inspiration. I hope you guys fight through this, it will never be easy but it will get better. Love you guys ❤️

snippet.textDisplay: My aunt passed away last April from cancer. When she got diagnosed she was on stage 4. They told her she only had about 2 months, but those two months became a year, and then she went into remission only to fall again. They told us it would only be two weeks, but thankfully she lived another year. She never stopped fighting for her life, she was afraid of death, but the last few weeks of her life she told us “ I’m not afraid anymore.” That will aLways have an impact on me. The first month of her passing I didn’t cry at all because I thought I had to be strong for my parents. I had to be the parent at that moment. That experience made me grow a lot as a person. And I guess the whole meaning of this is to say that it’s okay to cry it’s okay to let your emotions out. Don’t block emotions away those emotions hit you harder in the long run. You don’t always have to be strong. It’s okay to show signs of weaknesses. This documentary has touched me in many ways because I’ve felt numb towards a situation like that as well.

snippet.textDisplay: As a now 3 time cancer survivor and still going through surgery and recovery right now I thank you for this video 💚💜💖 For the truth of what patients and families go through with diagnosis, treatment, finances, transportation, treatment centers, mental health, and even loss(hair)/pain. I’ve been and seen it all starting when I was 11 years old and I just turned 42 on February 2nd. The first two times my family and I faced this pretty much alone. This time because I’ve been terrified of going through it again I’ve kept an eye on how to go about getting help and statistics of cancer... my cancer.  I’ve done nothing but reach out for help and even with doing that and research... well I’m just glad there are people like you that are able to help people who need help because you are right it’s heartbreaking 🥺 The silver lining this time is I get to keep my hair this time and only remember the handfuls of hair in my hands😳 Please continue to do good because it does matter ✨

snippet.textDisplay: To have had cancer myself... Everything around you shuts down. My name is Isabel, I'm only 17 years old, I got diagnosed August 14, 2016. I was only a baby. I still am.. Everyday I wake up blessed because I'm a lucky one. Now I volunteer @ Loma Linda where I had treatment and radiation. I love all my "children" there, they call me mommy izzy🤧❤️. It's hard, I lose kids everyday, and I gain them too. To see them suffer.. the only thing I know how to do best is to comfort them. I'd give my life for any of them, anyone really. I've watched you guys while treatment and I wanna thank you guys for being so freaking out going and strong with this. I'm really proud💙 Cancer sucks👎🏼 together we can beat it💗

snippet.textDisplay: I lost my dad to cancer when I was 14 I was numb I was angry and I was frustrated. I didnt cope well for years after. He died of cancer January 18, 2014. snippet.textDisplay: I'm not gonna lie, I've been avoiding this video. I knew your father died from cancer, and my grandma died from cancer too. Watching this made me see the love you had for your father and the love he had for others, he is beautiful. In every way. I really miss my grandma. I can no longer hear her voice, but she died when I was young. Just recently it has been 13 years. I can remember her, and the love she had serving others with endless love. Thank you for making me cry, it has been something I needed to get off my chest because it's been so long without her. I will keep you and your family and those he impacted in my prayers. We'll never fully heal, but we'll be able to get through it. 💙

snippet.textDisplay:
You guys are so brave to share your journey through grief with us. Loosing a parent is extremely devastating. This is an amazing thing you guys are doing but I so wish you didn't have to. My heart aches for your entire family.

To the viewers, if you cant donate to research or other cancer foundations financially please consider signing up to donate bone marrow at bethematch.org You could save a life. You might never be called but if you do you could not only save a life but also change lives. It's so painful. I won't lie but it's without a doubt the most rewarding thing I've ever done.
